bestBHT.bht: After their four to five-year mission, Paul and Barnabas returned to Antioch, marking a significant moment in the history of Christianity. They faithfully served God and endured persecutions, all while spreading the gospel and opening doors of usefulness. During their two-year stay in Antioch, they had disputes with some Christians who advocated for Jewish customs. Despite the challenges, their time in Antioch fostered fellowship and strengthened their bonds with believers. They chose not to report their work to Jerusalem, making it a fruitful and happy time of ministry.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: From the commencement of the mission till they left Antioch to go up to attend the council at Jerusalem, some four or five years elapsed."
The rest of the time would be the period of their stay at Antioch.
Albert Barnes: We may be certain that these holy men were not idle.
From the example of Paul and Barnabas as recorded in this chapter, we may learn to bear all persecutions and trials without a complaint.

Christians should remember that it is God who opens doors of usefulness; and they should regard it as a matter of thanksgiving that such doors are opened, and that they are permitted to spread the gospel, whatever toil it may cost, whatever persecution they may endure, whatever perils they may encounter.
Philip Schaff: The exact length of time during which they remained at Antioch is uncertain certainly not less than two years were spent by Paul and Barnabas in the Syrian capital.
Archibald T. Robertson: It was a happy time of fellowship.
A new corner has been turned in the history of Christianity.
Paul and Barnabas made no report to Jerusalem.
John Gill: Paul and Barnabas continued a considerable time at Antioch with the believers there."
They abode long time with the disciples."
What might detain them the longer, might be the disputes they had with some 'judaizing' Christians.

bhtAttempts.bht: After their mission, which lasted about four or five years, Paul and Barnabas finally returned to Antioch. This period of time marked a significant turning point in the history of Christianity, with the spreading of the gospel to various places. Despite the challenges and persecutions they faced, Paul and Barnabas faithfully served God and opened doors of usefulness through their ministry. Their stay in Antioch, lasting at least two years, was a time of fellowship and strengthening bonds with the believers. It was also during this time that they had disputes with some Christians who were advocating for adherence to Jewish customs. Overall, their time in Antioch was fruitful and they made no report to Jerusalem about their work.

After their four to five-year mission, Paul and Barnabas returned to Antioch, marking a significant moment in the history of Christianity. They faithfully served God and endured persecutions, all while spreading the gospel and opening doors of usefulness. During their two-year stay in Antioch, they had disputes with some Christians who advocated for Jewish customs. Despite the challenges, their time in Antioch fostered fellowship and strengthened their bonds with believers. They chose not to report their work to Jerusalem, making it a fruitful and happy time of ministry.

After spending around four to five years on their mission, Paul and Barnabas returned to Antioch—a pivotal moment in Christian history. Their faithful service and endurance through persecutions opened doors of usefulness to spread the gospel. During their two-year stay in Antioch, they engaged in disputes with some Christians who advocated for Jewish customs. Despite the challenges, their time in Antioch fostered fellowship and strengthened bonds with believers. They chose not to report their work to Jerusalem, resulting in a fruitful and joyous period of ministry.

After completing their mission, which spanned around four to five years, Paul and Barnabas returned to Antioch, a significant moment in the history of Christianity. Through their faithful service and endurance amidst persecution, they were able to open doors of usefulness for spreading the gospel. During their extended stay in Antioch, lasting at least two years, they engaged in disputes with certain Christians who promoted Jewish customs. Despite the challenges, their time in Antioch brought about fellowship and strengthened their bonds with fellow believers, as they chose not to report their work to Jerusalem.

After four to five years on their mission, Paul and Barnabas returned to Antioch, marking a turning point in Christian history. They faithfully served God, enduring persecutions and opening doors for the spread of the gospel. During their two-year stay in Antioch, they had disputes with Christians advocating for Jewish customs. Despite the challenges, their time there fostered fellowship and strengthened bonds with believers. They made no report to Jerusalem, emphasizing the fruitful and joyous nature of their ministry in Antioch.
